data.title: Prelude to what? Kunihild?
data.text:
On Feb 25, 10:38 am, Mike Scott Rohan

Post by Mike Scott Rohan

Post by REP

I was just playing from an ancient university-copy of the Lohengrin

vocal score and in the prelude, someone has circled one of the last

measures and labeled it "Prelude to Kunihild." Believing I knew

everything about the operatic literature, it took me a while to accept

that "Kunihild" was indeed the word written and that I was not

misreading it. So I finally googled "Kunihild" and discovered that a

German composer, Cyrill Kistler (1848-1907), had indeed written an

opera by that name.

According to the Wiki article, Kistler knew Wagner personally, and the

elder composer "described his friend Cyrill Kistler as his only

dignified successor." Interesting if true.

Anyways, Kistler's music appears entirely forgotten today, except by

the previous borrower of this Lohengrin vocal score and by high school

bands. That's right, the Prelude to Act 3 of Kunihild is available in

a number of different YouTube recordings. If you know the Lohengrin

prelude as well as I do, you won't need any help hearing the

http://youtu.be/E7yhhE7b_Jg

So has anyone heard more of his stuff? And did Wagner really praise

him so highly?

REP

He was undoubtedly a friend of Wagner's, a devoted Wagnerian and a

theoretician who did much to raise the technical opinion of Wagner's

music; small wonder if Wagner thought well of him. But he can only

have heard Kistler's earliest works, so the endorsement must be more

of the "promising" variety; he probably expected K to develop further

and become less sheerly imitative. In fact he didn't; this may have

been due to ill health, though he still wrote a great deal. It all

remained rather derivative, it seems. In a music text of 1905, the

year of Kistler's quite early death, I've found that he is described

as (approximately) "formerly thought of as Wagner's successor, but now

all his works have fallen into obscurity." As soon as that. Whereas

the same article describes the mighty post-Wagnerian charlatan of

similar vintage August Bungert in still quite laudatory terms. Kistler

was a much finer musician, and his works on harmony are still taken

very seriously. And he does have one plus to history -- it was a

performance of his opera Eulenspiegel that inspired Richard Strauss to

write his tone-poem.

What I hear in that prelude, incidentally, isn't Lohengrin but Rienzi,

lifted wholesale!

Cheers,

Mike

Bungert is another composer I'd never heard of before. An opera

tetralogy based on Homer is certainly intriguing, but for recordings,

all I can find is one half-assed MIDI realization of a prelude on

YouTube. It would be nice to hear more, but if that MIDI realization

is genuine, then there's a good reason why his music is forgotten.

The measure that this person had circled in the Lohengrin prelude, by

the way, was this one:

REP

Mike Scott Rohan

Post by REP

Bungert is another composer I'd never heard of before. An opera

tetralogy based on Homer is certainly intriguing, but for recordings,

all I can find is one half-assed MIDI realization of a prelude on

YouTube. It would be nice to hear more, but if that MIDI realization

is genuine, then there's a good reason why his music is forgotten.

The measure that this person had circled in the Lohengrin prelude, by

http://youtu.be/LMtRof9qJG8

REP

The only recordings of Bungert I'm aware of are a couple of his

lieder, on the classic Elena Gerhardt/Nikisch recordings, made when

she was only 22. I haven't heard them for years, but as I remember

they don't sound like anything very special.

If classical subjects appeal, incidentally, it's isn't Homer, but have

you ever heard Taneyev's Oresteia? Another operatic trilogy, and often

quite impressive, notably the rather Tannhauser-ish prelude to the

Apollo's temple at Delphi scene, which is the commonest excerpt. There

was an LP release on DG in the early 80s, but I haven't seen one

lately; however there are some snippets, arias etc on Youtube.

There's also an "overture", distinct from the score, which is more a

tone-poem of digested motifs, rather like Rimsky's Sadko but written

before rather than after; that's been recorded by Ashkenazy.

Cheers,

Mike
